interpElections

Spatial interpolation of electoral data via inverse distance weighting with per-zone optimized decay parameters.

interpElections disaggregates data collected at source points (e.g., polling locations) into target polygons (e.g., census tracts) using travel-time-based IDW weights. The decay parameter for each zone is calibrated against known demographic totals, and the resulting weights can then interpolate any variable — candidate votes, party totals, turnout, or custom data.

The package provides:

  • An analytical gradient for fast L-BFGS-B optimization on CPU and GPU-accelerated optimization via torch (ADAM on CUDA/MPS).
  • End-to-end Brazilian election helpers that auto-download census, electoral, and road-network data for any municipality.
  • A general-purpose API that works with any point-to-polygon disaggregation problem.

Installation

interpElections is not yet on CRAN. Install from GitHub:

# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("antrologos/interpElections")

Optional dependencies unlock additional capabilities:

Dependency What it enables
torch GPU-accelerated optimization (CUDA, MPS)
r5r + Java 21 Travel-time computation via the R5 routing engine
sf Spatial data handling (required for wrapper functions)

Run setup_torch(), setup_java(), or check_r5r() to configure these after installation.

Quick example 

library(interpElections)

# Bundled example: 20 tracts, 8 source points, 3 demographic groups
tt  <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/example_tt_matrix.rds",
                            package = "interpElections"))
pop <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/example_pop_matrix.rds",
                            package = "interpElections"))
src <- readRDS(system.file("extdata/example_source_matrix.rds",
                            package = "interpElections"))

# Find optimal per-zone decay parameters
result <- optimize_alpha(tt, pop, src, use_gpu = FALSE, verbose = FALSE)
result
#> interpElections optimization result
#>   Method: cpu_lbfgsb_parallel | Convergence: 0 (success)
#>   Objective: ...
#>   Alpha: n=20, mean=..., range=[..., ...]

# Interpolate any source-level data into the 20 tracts
candidate_votes <- matrix(rpois(16, 200), nrow = 8, ncol = 2,
                           dimnames = list(NULL, c("Party_A", "Party_B")))
interpolated <- idw_interpolate(tt, result$alpha, candidate_votes)

# Total conservation: source totals == tract totals
colSums(candidate_votes)
colSums(interpolated)

See vignette("introduction") for a full walkthrough: Getting Started with interpElections.

Brazilian elections in one call

For Brazilian municipal elections, a single function downloads census data, electoral results, road networks, computes travel times, and runs the full interpolation pipeline:

result <- interpolate_election_br(
  code_muni = 1400100,   # Boa Vista, RR (IBGE 7-digit code)
  year = 2020,           # Municipal election year
  what = "candidates"    # or "parties", "turnout", "demographics"
)

summary(result)
plot(result)

The package includes a crosswalk of all 5,710 Brazilian municipalities (data(muni_crosswalk)) mapping IBGE codes to TSE codes and state abbreviations.

See vignette("brazilian-elections") for the complete workflow: Interpolating Brazilian Electoral Data.

Custom data (non-Brazilian)

The interpolation engine is not limited to elections. Any point-to-polygon disaggregation problem works:

result <- interpolate_election(
  tracts_sf     = my_districts,
  electoral_sf  = my_schools,
  zone_id       = "district_id",
  point_id      = "school_id",
  calib_zones   = c("pop_young", "pop_old"),
  calib_sources = c("enroll_young", "enroll_old"),
  interp_sources = "budget",
  time_matrix   = my_distance_matrix
)

See vignette("custom-data") for a self-contained example with synthetic data: Using interpElections with Your Own Data.

How it works

For each tract i and source point j, the raw weight is:

Wij=(tij+1)−αiW_{ij} = (t_{ij} + 1)^{-\alpha_i}

where t is the travel time in minutes and α is a per-zone decay parameter. The weight matrix is then column-standardized so that each source distributes exactly 100% of its data across the tracts — guaranteeing total conservation.

The optimal α vector is found by minimizing the squared error between interpolated and observed demographic totals:

f(α)=∑i,k(V̂ik−Pik)2f(\alpha) = \sum_{i,k} \bigl(\hat{V}_{ik} - P_{ik}\bigr)^2

where V̂ = Wstd(α) × V (interpolated values) and P is the known population matrix. An analytical gradient makes this feasible for thousands of zones.

See vignette("understanding-the-model") for the full mathematical treatment: Understanding the IDW Interpolation Model.

Vignettes

interpElections ships with six vignettes that form a progressive tutorial:

# Vignette Description
1 Getting Started Installation, quick example, package overview
2 Understanding the Model Mathematical foundation: IDW weights, column standardization, calibration, gradient
3 Brazilian Elections End-to-end Brazilian workflow: one-call wrapper, step-by-step pipeline, TSE data
4 Custom Data Using the package with non-Brazilian point-to-polygon problems
5 Working with Results S3 methods, residual analysis, validation, areal aggregation
6 Performance & Configuration GPU/CPU setup, optimization tuning, cache management

Function reference

Core IDW engine

Function Purpose
idw_weights() Build column-standardized weight matrix from travel times and alpha
idw_interpolate() Apply IDW weights to transfer source data into target zones
idw_objective() Evaluate sum-of-squared-errors loss at a given alpha
idw_gradient() Analytical gradient of the objective (for L-BFGS-B)
optimize_alpha() Find optimal per-zone alpha via GPU (ADAM) or CPU (L-BFGS-B)

High-level wrappers

Function Purpose
interpolate_election() One-call interpolation from sf points to sf polygons
interpolate_election_br() Full Brazilian pipeline with auto-download

Brazilian data helpers

Function Purpose
br_prepare_population() Census population by age bracket per tract
br_prepare_tracts() Census tract geometries with population data
br_prepare_electoral() TSE electoral data aggregated to polling locations
br_download_votes() Raw candidate vote counts from TSE
br_download_turnout() Turnout and abstention data from TSE
br_download_geocode() Polling station coordinates from TSE
compute_travel_times() Travel-time matrix via r5r routing
download_r5r_data() OSM road network download for r5r

Areal aggregation

Function Purpose
areal_weights() Area-weighted intersection matrix between polygon layers
areal_interpolate() Aggregate interpolated data into larger zones

Setup and diagnostics

Function Purpose
setup_torch() / check_torch() Install and verify GPU (torch) support
setup_java() / check_r5r() Install and verify Java/r5r for travel times
setup_osmium() Install osmium for OSM data clipping
use_gpu() Toggle GPU acceleration on/off

Cache management

Function Purpose
get_interpElections_cache_dir() Show current cache location
set_interpElections_cache_dir() Change cache location
interpElections_cache() List cached files and sizes
interpElections_cache_clean() Delete cached data by category

GPU acceleration

For municipalities with more than ~1,000 census tracts, GPU acceleration provides significant speedups. The package supports NVIDIA GPUs (CUDA) and Apple Silicon (MPS):

setup_torch()           # one-time installation
use_gpu(TRUE)           # enable globally
result <- optimize_alpha(tt, pop, src)  # automatically uses GPU

See vignette("performance-and-configuration") for details: Performance Tuning and Configuration.
